text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with the bond me sandwich that's
right I don't do a lot of sandwiches
mostly because they're sandwiches but
here I'm making an exception because
this my friends is no ordinary sandwich
I mean if sandwiches were rides at an
amusement park the bond me would have
the longest line it's true sorry
liverwurst I mean this thing really is a
masterpiece of contrasting taste
textures and maybe most importantly
temperature so let's go ahead and get
started with the most important
ingredient the bread in fact in
Vietnamese behind me actually means
bread or wheat bread or I guess
technically bread wheat but anyway to
make a proper one you're going to need
one of these authentic French sandwich
rolls which should be super easy to find
at your friendly local neighborhood
French Vietnamese bakery but just in
case you don't have one of those near
you I will be showing you how to make
these yourself in an upcoming video so
definitely stay tuned for that because a
great sandwich roll is really not that
easy to find and pretty soon you won't
have to so we are going to need some
nice crusty rolls for this and once
we've taken care of that we can move on
to the almost as important secret sauce
which is generally some type of spicy
mayonnaise spread and while I can't tell
you what other people put in their
secret sauce because of the whole
secrecy thing I will show you what I put
in mine some real mayonnaise a spoon of
hoisin sauce which is going to provide a
very interesting brand of sweetness and
then last but not least a generous
splash of hot sauce and that's
surprisingly I'm going with sriracha and
we will take a spoon and mix that up and
that's it our subtly sweet and kind of
spicy mayonnaise bread is done so we'll
go ahead and stir that together and
simply reserved it until needed and of
course if that's going to be a while
we'll keep that in the fridge and once
our secret sauce is done we can move on
to another very key ingredient the
pickled vegetables so we'll start with
the con and if you've never seen a whole
when they grow embarrassingly large so
happily my local market just let me buy
a small piece off the top which believe
it or not was only like 20% of the whole
thing but anyway regardless of the size
we'll go ahead and trim off the end and
then cut this in half so it's a little
easier to julienne and we should
probably also go around with the knife
trimming off the skin and then what I'm
going to do is cut this in half and
Julianne using one of these Japanese
vegetable slicers and you can definitely
do the same thing using a knife
but this really is a nice school for
saving time as well as getting beautiful
uniform pieces assuming of course you
use the guard and don't slice your
fingertips off so do as I say not as you
see me doing
and by the way daikon are actually
pretty easy to find in supermarkets
these days but if you can't get them you
can just slice up some regular radish
and that would work okay here so we'll
go ahead and we'll julienne some daikon
and then do the exact same thing with
some carrot and personally I prefer a 1
to 1 ratio
daikon to carrot and with that I will
spare you any more vegetable slicing
footage and we will fast forward to a
mixing bowl containing those equal parts
carrots and radish at which point is
time to pickle these which traditionally
takes a couple days so we're going to
use a shortcut method which simply
involves tossing these in some seasoned
rice vinegar and letting them sit for
about 15 minutes or until the vegetables
kind of relax and lose their rigidity no
I said rigidity see when you first toss
these with the vinegar they're going to
feel like raw crisp firm pieces of
vegetable but as you'll see after about
15 minutes they kind of soften up just a
little bit
at which point those are ready to use
but not alone for a proper bond me
you're also going to need some thinly
sliced jalapeno peppers I also sliced up
a little bit of English cucumber and
then finally in addition to our now
quickly pickled vegetables we also want
a ton of fresh cilantro leaves and then
once our veggies are prepped we can move
to final bon meat production so what
we'll do is we'll take one of our French
rolls and split it in half but now hot
all the way through will cut it almost
all the way through and open it up and
then personally I do recommend removing
a little bit of that bread from the top
and that's for two reasons
one so we have enough room for all those
pickled vegetables we're going to pile
on but also now this qualifies as a low
carb sandwich
so while optional I do recommend that
step and then once I roll has been split
and possibly partially excavated we will
spread that liberally with our secret
sauce and I really do mean liberally you
really want to go for full coverage here
which as you can see I did not achieve I
blame the combination of going too fast
because I'm filming and trying to watch
what I'm doing in the viewfinder but
enough of my lame excuses the point is
use a ton of that sauce and spread it
over the entire surface and then what
we'll do is we'll transfer that to a
foil lined baking sheet and crisp that
up in a nice hot oven so we'll go ahead
and bake that at 400 degrees
about seven to ten minutes or until it's
heated through in those edges start to
brown at which point it should look
something like this and do not skip this
step a botany must be served on a hot
preferably crispy crusted roll and once
we have that we can start piling on our
meats which is hopefully going to be our
pan-roasted five-spice pork loin which
was presented in the last video so if
you haven't seen that check it out but
having said that there are lots of other
options which we will review on the blog
post so the choice of meat will be your
call you are after all the bond you of
your bond me
so we'll pile some of that on and then
after that no matter which meat you use
we're going to insist you also add a few
slices of pate in fact if you're making
this with other people and they don't
want the pate you really need to insist
the extra flavor and richness it
provides our key here so I really do
want you to fight for your right to pate
and know it doesn't have to be an
imported truffle studded goose liver
pate although that does work nicely but
any old pate will do
and then once our meat and hopefully
pate have been placed down we'll finish
this off with our veggies so I'm going
to first place down a little bit of
cucumber and then we'll top that with
our quick pickled daikon and carrots and
we really do want to be generous with
this stuff in fact I think I tried to
make this a little too neat for the
pictures and in hindsight if I was just
making this to eat I probably would put
on about twice as much of the veggies
but anyway we'll pile that up being very
generous with the amounts and then we'll
top that off with our sliced jalapeno as
well as copious amounts of our freshly
picked cilantro leaves and our sandwich
is pretty much done now normally at this
point this would be rolled and wrapped
tightly in butcher paper which holds
everything together so you can slice it
but I didn't think that would look as
good so I just kind of used my knife and
pressed it down and eventually got it
cut without losing too much revealing
your classic bonhomie cross-section so
pretty so I transferred that to a plate
and served it with some beet chips which
is a classic presentation no error but
really who cares about the sides when
we're talking about a sandwich like this
I mean just an incredible combination of
crisp hot bread that moist succulent
meats and hopefully rich buttery pate
and when you contrast that with those
cold crisp vegetables and spicy secret
sauce you're talking about a sandwich
that transcends sandwiches
even if you don't make this with your
own freshly roasted pork and fancy pate
and simply just use some slice deli
meats you're still going to be enjoying
one of the greatest sandwiches you've
ever had okay so I really do hope you
give this a try soon head over to food
wishes comm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
